dt: {bc}firmly established and generally accepted practice or procedure
{bc}a uniform certain reasonable lawful practice existing in a particular locality or occupation and binding persons entering into transactions chiefly on the basis of presumed familiarity
{bc}the way in which words and phrases are actually used (as in a particular form or sense) in a language community
{bc}the action, amount, or mode of using

pt: {sc}habit{/sc} {sc}practice{/sc} {sc}usage{/sc} {sc}custom{/sc} {sc}wont{/sc} mean a way of acting fixed through repetition. {sc}habit{/sc} implies a doing unconsciously and often compulsively.

pt.t: had a {it}habit{/it} of tapping his fingers

pt: {sc}practice{/sc} suggests an act or method followed with regularity and usually through choice.

pt.t: our {it}practice{/it} is to honor all major credit cards

pt: {sc}usage{/sc} suggests a customary action so generally followed that it has become a social norm.

pt.t: western-style dress is now common {it}usage{/it} in international business

pt: {sc}custom{/sc} applies to a practice or usage so steadily associated with an individual or group as to have almost the force of unwritten law.

pt.t: the {it}custom{/it} of wearing black at funerals

pt: {sc}wont{/sc} usually applies to a habitual manner, method, or practice of an individual or group.

pt.t: as was her {it}wont{/it}, she slept until noon

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French, from {it}us{/it} use
shortdef: firmly established and generally accepted practice or procedure
a uniform certain reasonable lawful practice existing in a particular locality or occupation and binding persons entering into transactions chiefly on the basis of presumed familiarity
the way in which words and phrases are actually used (as in a particular form or sense) in a language community
